questions.question: Mutation in which of the following genes causes Wilson's disease?
A 35-year-old man with tremors and chronic hepatitis is found to have the followingophthalmic finding. This patient is also likely to have which of the following?
questions.explanation: The given image shows the Kayser-Fleischer ring. This, along with the background of hepatitis andneuropsychiatric features is characteristic of Wilson's disease. The patient is thus likely to havebasal ganglia atrophy.In the majority of cases, neuropsychiatric manifestations follow hepatic manifestations. It is dueto the deposition of free copper in the basal ganglia and cortex. Free copper deposition in thebasal ganglia leads to bilateral degeneration and atrophy.

questions.question: 936Which of the following would you use to screen an asymptomatic sibling of a patient withWilson's disease?
questions.explanation: Genetic testing for the ATP7B gene is used to screen asymptomatic 1st and 2nd-degree relatives ofpatients with Wilson's disease. This helps to differentiate the heterozygous from the homozygousindividuals. This can be useful in the early initiation of treatment before the onset of symptoms.Low serum ceruloplasmin, raised 24 hr urinary copper and Kayser-Fleischer rings arediagnostically helpful.Estimation of hepatic tissue copper is the gold standard for diagnosis. It is measured usingneutron activation analysis / atomic absorption spectrometry.

questions.question: A 30-year-old male patient presented with personality changes and jaundice. Slit-lampexamination confirmed the diagnosis of Wilson's disease. Which of the following statementsis true regarding the condition?

options.A: Ceruloplasmin in blood increases and urinary copper excretion decreases
options.B: Ceruloplasmin in blood decreases and urinary copper excretion decreases
options.C: Ceruloplasmin in blood increases and urinary copper excretion increases
options.D: Ceruloplasmin in blood decreases and urinary copper excretion increases

questions.explanation: The ceruloplasmin level in the blood decreases, and the copper content in urine increases inWilson's disease.Lab markersChange in Wilson's diseasReasoneSerum ceruloplas↓↓min24h urinary coppe↑↑rATP7B deficiency results in reduced bound copperExcess free copper excreted in urine

questions.question: Which of the following stains can be used to demonstrate excess copper deposition inWilson's disease?
questions.explanation: 944Excess copper deposition in Wilson's disease is demonstrated by rhodanine stain.Microscopic findings in Wilson's disease include:•• Fatty infiltration (macrovesicular)Glycogen deposition in periportal hepatocytes• Macronodular cirrhosis in decompensated stages.Orcein stain is used to stain copper-associated proteins (eg: ceruloplasmin).

questions.question: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complainsof dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below.This patient most likely suffers from937
questions.explanation: The patient most likely suffers from hemochromatosis. In the given scenario, the liver microscopyimage shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with Perl's Prussian blue stain.Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder caused by excessive ironabsorption. Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as theliver and pancreas followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs.The image below shows the triad of haemochromatosis.Triad of hemochromatosisMicronodular cirrhosis(most common)Diabetes mellitusTriad ofhemochromatosisBronzing of skinThe image below is the liver microscopy image showing hepatocellular iron, stained with Perl'sPrussian blue.945Hemochromatosis - Prussian blue stainingIron accumulationin hepatocytesThe total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults. In hemochromatosis, total ironaccumulation may exceed 50 gm, more than one-third of which accumulates in the liver.

questions.question: A patient with hereditary hemochromatosis is found to have a mutation in the HFE gene. Onwhich chromosome is it located?
questions.explanation: HFE gene is located on the short arm of chromosome 6 (6p). It is the most commonly mutatedgene in patients with hereditary hemochromatosis.HFE encodes an HLA class I-like molecule that regulates the synthesis of hepcidin in hepatocytes.The most common HFE mutation is a cysteine-to-tyrosine substitution at amino acid 282(C282Y).

questions.question: A 34-year-old man evaluated for chronic abdominal pain is found to have hepatomegaly andserum ferritin level of 1800 micro g/l. Which of the following complications is he at thegreatest risk of developing?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemochromatosis. A patient with hemochromatosis isat risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma.Hepatocellular carcinoma is a significant cause of death in hemochromatosis. The risk is muchgreater than in the general population.The disease progression of hemochromatosis is as shown below:946Disease progression of hemochromatosisHealthy liverChronic hepatitisMALLOWMicronodular cirrhosisHepaticdecompensationOMARROWHepatocellular carcinoma(more common)

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding hemochromatosis?
questions.explanation: Neonatal hemochromatosis is not an inherited disease. It is a disease of unknown originmanifested by severe liver disease and extrahepatic hemosiderin deposition. It might be related tomaternal alloimmune injury to the fetal liver.Adult hemochromatosis is generally a milder disease than the juvenile form. With treatment, lifeexpectancy is normal.Bantu siderosis or African iron overload is due to dietary iron overload. Consumption of beerprepared in iron pots or drums is the cause of dietary iron overload.Skin pigmentation in hemochromatosis mostly results from increased melanin synthesis. Thisis due to iron deposition and not hemosiderin deposition.In severe hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm. More than one-third ofthis accumulates in the liver. In normal adults, it is in the range of 2 to 6 gms.

questions.question: Which of the following organs does not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis?
questions.explanation: The testes do not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis.Hypogonadism in hemochromatosis is not due to the deposition of iron in the testis. It is due to aderangement in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. This results in decreased gonadotrophins andtestosterone levels. The testis will appear small and atrophic.Deposition of hemosiderin is seen in the following organs in the decreasing order of severity:• Liver• Pancreas• Myocardium947•Pituitary gland• Adrenal gland• Thyroid• Parathyroid gland•• Joints• Skin

questions.question: A 35-year-old male patient with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases.His liver biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?939
questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The liverbiopsy image shows periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant round-to-ovalcytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes. These are characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsindeficiency.It is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1antitrypsin into the serum. α1AT deficiency results in excessive degradation of alveoli byneutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema. It also causes liver disease as a consequence ofan abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. Cutaneous necrotizingpanniculitis also occurs in a minor subset of patients. Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in 2% to3% of cases.The image given is a photomicrograph of a liver biopsy from a patient with alpha-1 antitrypsindeficiency. The PAS with diastase stain shows the diastase-resistant pink globules that arecharacteristic of this disease.Alpha 1-antitrypsin deficiency - Liver Biopsy

questions.question: On which chromosome is the gene for alpha-1 antitrypsin present?
questions.explanation: PAS +ve and diastaseresistant globules948The gene for alpha-1 antitrypsin is located on the long arm of chromosome 14. Alpha-1 antitrypsinis a plasma glycoprotein synthesized predominantly by hepatocytes.For α1-antitrypsin genes, the general notation is "Pi" for "protease inhibitor." An alphabetic letteris given for the position on the isoelectric gel.This gene has different alleles that produce different amounts of alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT).•M allele normal levels of the AAT protein• S allele moderately low levels•-Z allele very low levels-The alleles are expressed in a codominant manner.

questions.question: What is the most common clinically significant mutation causing alpha-1 antitrypsindeficiency?
questions.explanation: The most common clinically significant mutation causing α1-antitrypsin deficiency isPiZ. Homozygous individuals, with PiZZ, have only 10% of normal circulating α1-antitrypsin. So,they are at high risk of developing clinical disease.PiMM is the most common genotype seen in normal individuals, present in about 90% ofindividuals.PiS variant is clinically asymptomatic.Pi-null is a rare variant with no detectable serum alpha-1 antitrypsin.

questions.question: An 11-year-old girl with persistently elevated serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) andalanine aminotransferase (ALT) has been diagnosed with autoimmune hepatitis. Which of thefollowing pathological features would you not expect in this patient?
questions.explanation: Bile duct injury and granulomas are uncommon in autoimmune hepatitis except in case of overlapwith primary biliary cirrhosis.Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by extensive inflammation, fibrosis and ultimatelycirrhosis. The pathologic features include:.• Emperipolesis - Lymphocytes and plasma cells within the cytoplasm of hepatocytes.• Interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis.•• Rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration.The image given below shows autoimmune hepatitis with lymphoplasmacytic interface hepatitis.949Autoimmune hepatitisLymphoplasmacyticLiver lobuleinterface hepatitisPortal tract

questions.question: 940Which of the following statements is false with regard to autoimmune hepatitis?

options.A: Type 2 autoimmune hepatitis shows antinuclear antibodies (ANA).
options.C: It can progress to liver failure.
options.D: Inflammatory infiltrate is predominantly composed of plasma cells.

questions.explanation: Type 2 autoimmune hepatitis shows anti-liver kidney microsomal autoantibodies (anti-LKM1) andanti-liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) antibodies not ANA.Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis shows anti-nuclear (ANA), anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA)and anti-soluble liver antigen / liver pancreas antigen (anti-SLA/LP) antibodies. It less commonlyshows anti-mitochondrial (AMA) antibodies.Autoimmune hepatitis is a chronic disorder characterized by continuing hepatocellular necrosisand inflammation. It can progress to cirrhosis and liver failure.Histocompatibility haplotypes such as HLA-B1, HLA-B8, HLA-DR3, and HLA-DR4 are commonin patients with autoimmune hepatitis.950Histopathological features include:• Plasma cell predominance in inflammatory infiltrates• Extensive interface hepatitis (piecemeal necrosis)•• Hepatocyte rosettesThe image given below shows autoimmune hepatitis showing characteristic lymphoplasmacyticinfiltrate and interface hepatitis.

questions.question: Which of the following antibodies would you not expect to see in a patient with autoimmunehepatitis?
questions.explanation: Anti-TIF1y antibodies are not associated with autoimmune hepatitis. Anti-TIF1y antibodies arefound in patients with dermatomyositis.

questions.explanation: Chronic hepatitis D is associated with anti-LKM 3 antibodies.

questions.question: The histopathological findings obtained after a liver biopsy is given below. What would be themost probable diagnosis?941
questions.explanation: Onion-skin fibrosis is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis.The smaller ducts in primary sclerosing cholangitis show a striking circumferential "onion skin"fibrosis around an increasingly atrophic duct lumen. This eventually leads to the obliteration by a"tombstone" scar.The image shows primary sclerosing cholangitis. There is a degenerating bile duct that isentrapped in the dense concentric onion-skin fibrosis.951OnionskinfibrosisPrimary Sclerosing Cholangitis

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of primary sclerosing cholangitis?
questions.explanation: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis ofintrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. There is dilation of preserved segments.On histopathologic examination, large ducts show acute neutrophilic inflammation of theepithelium. The inflamed areas develop strictures. Small ducts show onion-skin fibrosis aroundthe atrophic duct lumen. There is an obliteration of ducts by a tombstone scar.

questions.question: Primary biliary cholangitis is most commonly associated with which of the followingconditions?
questions.explanation: Primary biliary cholangitis is most commonly associated with Sjogren's syndrome. Otherassociated conditions are:•Thyroiditis• Scleroderma• Rheumatoid arthritis•Raynaud phenomenon• Celiac diseasePBC is an autoimmune disease. It is characterized by nonsuppurative, inflammatory destructionof small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. Large intrahepatic ducts and the extrahepaticbiliary tree are not involved. It is a disease of middle-aged women, with a female predominance of9:1. Antimitochondrial antibodies are the most characteristic laboratory finding in PBC.Histopathologic examination shows diagnostic florid duct lesions. These are lymphoplasmacyticinfiltrates with or without granulomas centred around the bile duct. They also showMallory-Denk bodies.952The image given below shows primary biliary cholangitis.Primary biliary cholangitisPrimary biliary cholangitisBile duct withintraepitheliallymphocytesFlorid duct lesion showinglymphoplasmacytic infiltrate andgranuloma953
